content.question:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>x</mi> </math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>f</mi> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </math> is a real number.

The function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> has derivatives of all orders for all real numbers. It is known that <math alttext="f of 0 equals 2" overflow="scroll"> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>2</mn> </math>, <math alttext="f prime of 0 equals 3" overflow="scroll"> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>3</mn> </math>, <math alttext="f double prime of x equals, negative f of, open parenthesis, x squared, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>′</mo> <mo>′</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="2.4ex" width="0.0em"> </mspace> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, and <math alttext="f triple prime of x equals, negative 2 x times, f prime of, open parenthesis, x squared, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>′</mo> <mo>′</mo> <mo>′</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mpadded> <mo>−</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> <mo>·</mo> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <msup> <mi>x</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="2.4ex" width="0.0em"> </mspace> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </math>.

(a) Find <math alttext="the fourth derivative of f of x" overflow="scroll"> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mn>4</mn> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </math>, the fourth derivative of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mi>f</mi> </math> with respect to <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"> <mi>x</mi> </math>. Write the fourth-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> about <math alttext="x equals 0" overflow="scroll"> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

frqParts.text:
NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>x</mi> </math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>f</mi> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </math> is a real number.

The function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> has derivatives of all orders for all real numbers. It is known that <math alttext="f of 0 equals 2" overflow="scroll"> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>2</mn> </math>, <math alttext="f prime of 0 equals 3" overflow="scroll"> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>3</mn> </math>, <math alttext="f double prime of x equals, negative f of, open parenthesis, x squared, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>′</mo> <mo>′</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msup> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="2.4ex" width="0.0em"> </mspace> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>, and <math alttext="f triple prime of x equals, negative 2 x times, f prime of, open parenthesis, x squared, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>′</mo> <mo>′</mo> <mo>′</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mpadded> <mo>−</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> <mo>·</mo> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mo>′</mo> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <msup> <mi>x</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="2.4ex" width="0.0em"> </mspace> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </math>.

(a) Find <math alttext="the fourth derivative of f of x" overflow="scroll"> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mn>4</mn> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </math>, the fourth derivative of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mi>f</mi> </math> with respect to <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"> <mi>x</mi> </math>. Write the fourth-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> about <math alttext="x equals 0" overflow="scroll"> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </math>. Show the work that leads to your answer.

(b) The fourth-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mi>f</mi> </math> about <math alttext="x equals 0" overflow="scroll"> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </math> is used to approximate <math alttext="f of 0.1" overflow="scroll"> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>0.1</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </math>. Given that <math alttext="the absolute value of, the fifth derivative of f of x, end absolute value, is less than or equal to 15" overflow="scroll"> <mrow> <mo>|</mo> <msup> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>5</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>|</mo> </mrow> <mo>≤</mo> <mn>15</mn> </math> for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 0.5" overflow="scroll"> <mn>0</mn> <mo>≤</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>≤</mo> <mn>0.5</mn> </math>, use the Lagrange error bound to show that this approximation is within <math alttext="the fraction 1 over 10 to the fifth power, end fraction" overflow="scroll"> <mfrac> <mn>1</mn> <msup> <mn>10</mn> <mn>5</mn> </msup> </mfrac> </math> of the exact value of <math alttext="f of 0.1" overflow="scroll"> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>0.1</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </math>.

(c) Let <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> be the function such that <math alttext="g of 0 equals 4" overflow="scroll"> <mi>g</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mn>0</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mn>4</mn> </math> and <math alttext="g prime of x equals, e to the x power, times f of x" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mo>′</mo> </mrow> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <msup> <mrow> <mi>e</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> </mrow> </msup> <mo>⁢</mo> <mi>f</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. Write the second-degree Taylor polynomial for <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> about <math alttext="x equals 0" overflow="scroll"> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </math>.

topic.text: 10.11: (BC ONLY) Finding Taylor Polynomial Approximations of Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
